授業方法: Face to face format. Most classes will involve a lecture component followed by whole-class and small-group discussions. Groups will sometimes be asked to make impromptu speeches to summarize the contents of discussion. The final few classes of the semester will be dedicated to student presentations. You should have a stable wifi or internet connection at home to complete all out-of-class assignments.

第1回:
**The course contents are subject to change dependent on the information received from the students' needs analyses. The needs analyses will be done during the first class of the semester.

Students will complete two sections of this course: 1) intercultural communication foundations, and 2) applied intercultural communication. First, the foundations component of the course will involve the role of culture in communication and how intercultural competences may improve the chances of successful cross-cultural interactions, especially in Japan. With an understanding of culture as distinct, yet fluid, the second stage of the course examines the intercultural foundations in practice.

Introductions, ice breakers, needs analysis
第2回:
Section 1: Intercultural Communication Foundations
Culture conceptualized and defined
第3回: Exploring the veracity of national dimensions of culture: Hofstede and Trompenaars & Hampden-Turner
第4回: The role of national and personal identity in culture
第5回:
Section 2: Applied Intercultural Communication
Cultural values and intercultural considerations in Japanese society: a focus on etiquette
第6回: Introduction to final presentation, team discussion on cross-cultural etiquette
第8回: Presentation and discussion: Tokyo 2020 and its cultural legacy
第9回: Presentation and discussion: gender and sexuality issues across cultures
第10回: Presentation and discussion: nonverbal communication across cultures
第11回: Presentation and discussion: the role of religion and spirituality on culture and communication
第12回: Presentation and discussion: cross-cultural communication and the university experience: a comparative analysis
第13回: Presentation and discussion: the role of family and housing on adult lifestyle and perspective
第14回: Presentation and discussion: language issues; does language influence thought and actions?
トピック.授業外学習2: Students are expected to attend class regularly and dedicate approximately two hours a week towards homework. Homework assignments include weekly journals that provide the basis for the following week’s lesson. Essentially, the journal assignment will allow students to prepare for the following week’s discussion.  Also, students will be expected to make a team presentation of approximately 20 minutes on a theme related to course content. You should have a stable wifi or internet connection at home to complete all out-of-class assignments.
